prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone in preschool would. If the odds for pulling a prize out of the box are $3:4$, what is the probability of not pulling the prize out of the box? Express your answer as a common fraction.
solution: If the odds for pulling a prize out of the box are $3:4$, that means that 3 out of 7 times will result in a prize, while 4 out of 7 times will not. So the probability of not pulling the prize out of the box is $\boxed{\frac{4}{7}}$.
gpt_response: If I pull $3$ times, I will get a prize $3$ times and not get a prize $4$ times. So the probability of not pulling a prize out of the box is $4$ out of $7$ or $\frac{4}{7}$.
solution_prompt: Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following equal to \frac{4?: If I pull $3$ times, I will get a prize $3$ times and not get a prize $4$ times. So the probability of not pulling a prize out of the box is $4$ out of $7$ or $\frac{4}{7}$.
